questions.text:
A resident is doing an abdominal examination in a primigravida. Sequentially arrange the respective uses of Leopold's First maneuver, Leopold's second maneuver, Leopold's third maneuver, and Leopold's fourth maneuver in the corresponding order
  1. Determine the degree of descent
  2. Confirmation of fetal presentation
  3. Determine the fetal orientation
  4. Determine which fetal pole occupies the fundus.
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 4, 3, 2, 1:

Leopold First maneuvre - Determine which fetal pole occupies the fundus

Leopold second maneuver - Determine the fetal orientation

Leopold third maneuver - Confirmation of fetal presentation

Leopold fourth maneuver - Determine the degree of descent

Leopold’s first maneuver (fundal grip) is used to determine which fetal pole occupies the fundus.

Leopold’s second maneuver (lateral grip) can be used to determine the fetal orientation based on whether the back is facing anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly. The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen and gentle deep pressure is exerted. The fetal back is felt as a hard-resistant structure and the fetal limbs are felt as multiple small irregular parts.

Leopold’s third maneuver (Pawlik’s grip) helps to confirm fetal presentation. It is done by grasping the lower part of the maternal abdomen with the thumb and fingers of one hand. The palpation of a hard and round mass indicates that the presenting part is the fetal head. A movable mass suggests that the presenting part is not engaged. If the presenting part is breech, it is felt as a large nodular mass.

Leopold’s fourth maneuver (pelvic grip) helps to determine the degree of descent. The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part. They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.

questions.text: A pregnant woman comes to you in her second stage of labor. On per vaginal examination, frontal sutures, anterior fontanelle, and supraorbital ridges are palpated. What could the fetal presentation be?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the fetus could be in the brow presentation.

On per vaginal examination, the palpation of frontal sutures, anterior fontanelle, and supraorbital ridges indicate that the fetus is in the brow presentation. However, neither the mouth nor the chin can be palpated on per vaginal examination.

This is a rare presentation that is diagnosed when the portion of the fetal head between the orbital ridge and the anterior fontanel presents at the pelvic inlet.

The etiology of brow presentation includes:

  • Maternal: Multiparity with pendulous abdomen, lateral obliquity of the uterus, contracted pelvis.
  • Fetal: Congenital malformations with the most common being anencephaly, congenital goiter, dolichocephalic head

The brow presentation is commonly unstable and frequently converts to a face or occipital presentation. Management is easy in the case of a small fetus and a large maternal pelvis. However, in the case of a large fetus, delivery by cesarean section is usually indicated.

Other options:

Option A: Face presentation occurs when the neck is hyper-extended and the chin is the presenting part. The facial features may be palpable on per-vaginal examination. 

Option B: Vertex presentation occurs when the neck is well flexed. A quadrangular area of the fetal skull bound by the bregma, parietal eminence, and lambdoid sutures is palpable on per-vaginal examination.

Option D: Shoulder presentation can occur when the fetus is in the transverse lie. On per vaginal examination during labor, the shoulder is identified by palpating the following parts—the acromion process, the scapula, the clavicle, and the axilla. The characteristic landmarks are
the feeling of the ribs and intercostal spaces (gridiron feel). On occasion, the arm is found prolapsed.

questions.text: Match the engaging diameters marked on the fetal head with the presentations they correspond to.
questions.solution:
The correct matching is 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c.

In the above figure,

  • 1 represents the submento-bregmatic diameter
  • 2 represents the mento-vertical diameter
  • 3 represents the occipitofrontal diameter
  • 4 represents the suboccipito-bregmatic diameter

The engaging diameters of various presentations are:

Diameters Measurement in cm (inches) The attitude of the head Presentation
Suboccipitobregmatic 9.5 cm Complete flexion Vertex
Suboccipito-frontal 10 cm Incomplete flexion Vertex
Occipitofrontal 11.5 cm Marked deflexion Vertex
Mento-vertical 14 cm Partial extension Brow
Submentovertical 11.5 cm Incomplete extension Face
Submentobregmatic 9.5 cm Complete extension Face

questions.text: A mother of a newborn noticed vaginal discharge on her sixth-day postpartum. It was explained to the patient that the discharge was called lochia, and it is a normal finding postpartum. Arrange the correct order of the appearance of lochia.
questions.solution:
The correct order of appearance of lochia is rubra-serosa-alba.

Lochia refers to the vaginal discharge resulting from the sloughing of decidual tissue in the early puerperal period. 

Name Colour Timings after delivery Contents
Lochia Rubra Red First few days  Blood, decidua, fetal membranes, Vernix, lanugo, meconium
Lochia Serosa Yellowish/pink After 3 to 4 days WBCs, cervical mucus, micro-organisms
Lochia Alba Pale White After 10th day Decidua, cells, WBC, mucin, cholesterin crystals and fat cells 

The average amount of discharge for the first week is 250 mL and may persist for about 3 weeks.

Malodorous lochia may signify underlying infection. Copious or absent lochia may also indicate infection or lochiometra. The persistence of lochia rubra beyond the normal limit may signify subinvolution or retained bits of the conceptus. Prolonged discharge of lochia alba for more than 3 weeks may signify local genital lesion.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a twin pregnancy at 24 weeks of gestation came for a regular antenatal check-up.  She has had an abortion at 12 weeks of gestation five years back and healthy twins were delivered at term three years ago. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score?
questions.solution:
This woman has had three pregnancies in total (previous abortion, previous twin pregnancy, and current twin pregnancy) with the first pregnancy aborted in the first trimester (12 weeks) and the second pregnancy resulting in the delivery of twins at term. Therefore, her obstetric score would be G3P1A1L2 (Gravida - 3, Para - 1, Abortion - 1, Live birth - 2).

Gravida indicates the number of times a female has been pregnant. It includes present as well as past pregnancy, irrespective of the period of gestation.

Para indicates the number of previous pregnancies that had progressed beyond the period of viability (28 weeks of gestation or more).

Terminologies used in pregnancy:

  1. A nullipara is one who has never completed a pregnancy to the stage of viability. She may or may not have aborted previously.
  2. A nulligravida is one who is not now and never has been pregnant.
  3. A primipara is one who has delivered one viable child. Parity is not increased even if the fetuses are many (twins, triplets).
  4. A primigravida is one who is pregnant for the first time.
  5. A multigravida is one who has previously been pregnant. She may have aborted or have delivered a viable baby.
  6. A multipara is one who has completed two or more pregnancies to the stage of viability or more. A pregnant woman with a previous history of four births or more is called a grand multipara.

It is customary in clinical practice to summarise the past obstetric history by 2 digits

First digit: Number of viable births
Second digit: Number of abortions
Both digits connected with a “+” sign affixing the letter P.
Thus, P1+2 denotes patient had 1 viable birth and 2 abortions.

In this woman, it is denoted as P2+1 as the patient had twin delivery at term and 1 abortion.


In some centres, it is expressed by 4 digits connected by dashes, P(A-B-C-D)
A: Number of term pregnancies (37-42 weeks)
B: Number of preterm pregnancies (28 to less than 37 weeks)
C: Number of miscarriages (less than 28 weeks)
D: Number of children alive at present.

Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.

questions.text:
The physiological changes occurring in the respiratory system during pregnancy include:
  1. A decrease in total lung capacity
  2. A decrease in tidal volume
  3. Increase in respiratory minute volume
  4. Decrease in pulmonary resistance
questions.solution:
The physiological changes occurring in the respiratory system during pregnancy include 1, 3, and 4. In pregnancy, the tidal volume is increased (not decreased).

Physiological changes in the respiratory system during pregnancy:

  • Decrease in total lung capacity: This occurs due to the elevation of the diaphragm by the enlarged uterus.
  • Reduced pulmonary resistance due to the effect of progesterone.
  • Increase in tidal volume and respiratory minute volume, due to the action of progesterone on the respiratory center and increased sensitivity of the respiratory center to CO2. As a result, the woman may feel shortness of breath.
  • Increase in the subcostal angle from 68° to 103°.
  • Increase in the transverse diameter of the chest by 2 cm and chest circumference by 5-7 cm.
  • Edema and hyperemia of the nasopharyngeal mucosa may occur leading to nasal stuffiness and rarely epistaxis.

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida who conceived dichorionic diamniotic twins presented at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination, the first twin was found to be in cephalic presentation and the second twin in breech presentation. All of the following can be undertaken for delivery except?

choices.text: Vaginal delivery of 1st twin, breech extraction of 2nd twin
Vaginal delivery of 1st twin, internal podalic version of 2nd twin
Vaginal delivery of 1st twin, external cephalic version and delivery of 2nd twin

questions.solution:
All of the above-mentioned measures can be undertaken in this case except vaginal delivery of 1st twin and internal podalic version of 2nd twin.

The internal podalic version is an obstetric procedure in which the baby is turned inside the uterus such that the feet present through the cervix. Upward pressure is applied by the abdominal hand on the head while downward traction is exerted on the feet and the baby is then delivered by breech extraction. It is indicated when the second twin is in a transverse lie, not breech. This procedure is always done under general or epidural anesthesia.

When the first twin is cephalic and the second is non-cephalic, the following methods can be used:

  • Breech extraction of the second twin
  • C-section of both twins
  • An external cephalic version of the second twin
  • Rarely, cesarean section of the second twin following vaginal delivery of the first

The ACOG recommends termination of pregnancy at 38 weeks of pregnancy in dichorionic gestations. Cesarean section is preferred when the first twin is in a breech position. An attempted vaginal delivery can cause locking of the fetuses, trapping of the fetal head above the cervix, and umbilical cord prolapse.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old lady who underwent suction evacuation for molar pregnancy visits you on postoperative week 8 for her follow-up. Which of the following is not done during the follow-up of this patient?
  1. Ask her for a history of any irregular vaginal bleeding, cough, or breathlessness.
  2. Perform an abdominal examination to look for the size of the uterus and the ovaries.
  3. Perform a pelvic examination to look for sub-urethral nodules
  4. Request for a serum hCG value, a pelvic ultrasound, and chest X-ray PA view 
  5. Insert a copper-T device to avoid pregnancy
questions.solution:
Insertion of a copper-T device to avoid pregnancy is not done during follow-up of this patient.

Intrauterine devices are contraindicated post-evacuation of molar pregnancy due to the increased risk of perforation. Intrauterine devices and progestogen-only pills cause irregular bleeding and are best avoided as they lead to suspicion of malignancy. Safer contraceptive choices for such patients include combined oral pills, injectable DMPA(depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate), progestin implant, barrier methods, and sterilization.

Contraception has to be adopted by all patients who underwent suction curettage until HCG levels become undetectable and remain the same for a period of 6 months. This serves to avoid pregnancy and confusion regarding the source of HCG if there is a subsequent rise. After beta HCG levels have become normal, subsequent conception must be avoided for one year(preferably 2 years). Pregnancy should also be avoided for 1 year after the stoppage of chemotherapy because of the teratogenic effect of drugs.

All patients should be followed-up for 2 years because choriocarcinoma if it occurs, develops within this period of the evacuation of the mole. Commonly, the circulating levels of βhCG decrease or becomes negative within 4 to 8 weeks post evacuation. Once negative, the patient is usually followed up monthly for 6 months, then 3 monthly in the first year, and 6 monthly in the second year.

During follow-up visits, history should be taken about symptoms like irregular bleeding (choriocarcinoma), presence of nodules, cough, breathlessness, and hemoptysis (metastasis). An abdominal examination should be done to check for involution of the uterus and ovarian size. A pelvic examination is done to look for sub-urethral nodules (anterior vaginal wall).

Lab investigations must include routine investigations like haemogram, renal function, liver function test, and urine routine. Specific investigations include thyroid function tests and serum βhCG (by radio-immunoassay). Persistently high values indicate pregnancy or invasive mole.

Radiological investigations should include a chest X-ray PA view to look for lung metastases (classic cannon-ball appearance can be seen). Pelvic ultrasound is also done for surveillance. Myometrial or suburethral nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia. 

The given image shows the classical cannon-ball appearance on the chest X-ray.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and FIGO staging of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

Risk factors

  • Older age
  • β-hCG levels > 100,000 mIU/mL
  • Uterine size that is large-forgestational age
  • Theca-lutein cysts > 6 cm
  • Slow decline in β-hCG levels
  • Postevacuation uterine sonographic surveillance showing myometrial nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia.

FIGO staging:

Stage I Disease confined to the uterus
Stage II GTD extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structure
Stage III Lung metastasis with or without genital tract involvement
Stage IV Other metastasis

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by the arrow in the image below) giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: An anxious pregnant woman came to you for a second opinion with the report of her biochemical screening tests. An increased level of  human chorionic gonadotropin(hCG), as compared to normal pregnancy hCG levels, can be seen in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
The levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) are decreased in ectopic pregnancy when compared to the level of hCG in normal intrauterine pregnancy. 

In comparison to hCG levels in normal pregnancy, increased levels of hCG are found in:

  • Hydatidiform mole or choriocarcinoma
  • Trisomy 21 fetus
  • Multiple pregnancies

Decreased levels of hCG as compared to normal pregnancy hCG levels are found in:

  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Spontaneous abortion

Human chorionic gonadotropin is a glycoprotein. It can be detected in the maternal serum or urine as early as 8–9 days postfertilization. Maximum levels in blood and urine are found between 60 - 70 days of pregnancy. It disappears from the circulation within 2 weeks following delivery.

hCG is chemically and functionally similar to the pituitary luteinizing hormone (LH). The α subunit is biochemically similar to LH, FSH (follicular stimulating hormone), and TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone) whereas the β subunit is relatively unique to hCG.

Functions of hCG are:

  • It stimulates the secretion of progesterone by the corpus luteum during pregnancy
  • Rescue and maintenance of corpus luteum till 6 weeks of pregnancy
  • It stimulates Leydig cells of the male fetus to produce testosterone in conjunction with fetal pituitary gonadotropins
  • It inhibits the maternal processes of immune rejection of the fetus as a homograft.
  • Stimulates both adrenal and placental steroidogenesis.
  • Stimulates maternal thyroid because of its thyrotropic activity.
  • Promotes secretion of relaxin from the corpus luteum.

Related Pearl: Beta hCG in pregnancy

The pattern of beta hCG :

First detectable in plasma 7 to 9 days post-LH surge
          ⇓
Doubles every 2 days
          ⇓
Peaks at 8 to 10 weeks of gestation(~100 IU/mL)
          ⇓
Begins to decline at 10 to 12 weeks
          ⇓
Plateau at 16 weeks till term
 
  • Higher maternal plasma hCG levels- Multifetal pregnancy, erythroblastosis fetalis, gestational trophoblastic disease, Down syndrome.
  • Lower hCG plasma levels -early pregnancy wastage and ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the marked incision shown below?

choices.text: The rectus abdominis muscles are transected
Follows Langer lines of skin tension
Lower incidence of incisional hernias as compared to vertical incisions
Location is 3 cm above the pubic symphysis

questions.solution:
The incision marked is the Pfannenstiel incision where the rectus muscles are not transected. The rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

Pfannenstiel incision is the most common incision made in cesarean delivery.It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

Compared to vertical incisions, the Pfannenstiel incision offers superior cosmesis and lower incisional hernia rates.

The Maylard incision (the unmarked incision in the image) differs mainly from the Pfannenstiel in that the bellies of the rectus abdominis muscles are transected horizontally to widen the operating space.

Related Pearl: Transverse and vertical incisions in Cesarean section

Transverse Incisions Vertical incisions

Advantages

  • Follows Langer lines of skin tension, so superior cosmetic results
  • Less Postoperative pain
  • Less fascial wound dehiscence
  • Low incidence of incisional hernias

Advantages

  • Quick entry
  • Minimal blood loss
  • Superior access to the upper
    abdomen
  • Wide operating space
  • Flexibility for easy wound extension if necessary

Disadvantages

  • High infection risks
  • Narrow operating space
  • Injury to neurovascular bundles
  • Reentry during repeat C-section is difficult due to scarring 

Disadvantages

  • Poor cosmetic results
  • Higher fascial dehiscence 
  • Higher incisional hernia rates
  • Greater postoperative pain

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman with a previous history of preterm delivery presents at 32 weeks with intermittent uterine contractions. To allow for fetal lung maturity, what is the dose of betamethasone to be given?
questions.solution:
To allow for fetal lung maturity, the dose of betamethasone to be given is 12mg IM 24 hourly 2 doses.

Antenatal corticosteroids are recommended in a pregnancy less than 34 weeks to allow fetal lung maturation and to reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome(RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage(IVH), and necrotizing enterocolitis(NEC). 

Betamethasone is the steroid of choice and it becomes useful if the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours of the first dose with the effect lasting for about 18 days. Dexamethasone is another steroid that can be given in a dose of 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses IM.  

Short-term therapy with tocolytics is given in conjunction with steroids for 1-3 days to delay labour for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). The drugs include terbutaline, indomethacin, nifedipine, and atosiban. Contraindications to tocolysis include chorioamnionitis, preeclampsia/eclampsia, fetal distress, pregnancy >34 weeks, active labor, and placental abruption.

Preterm labour is the onset of labour before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of gestation). It can occur in patients with a history of prior preterm birth, multiple pregnancies and genital tract infection. Evaluation of cervical anatomy is the most important step in women with a history of preterm labour to look for cervical incompetence. 

Features of preterm labour include regular uterine contractions at least once every 10 minutes, with/without pain, cervical dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80% and length of cervix <2.5 cm and funnelling of the internal os >1 cm.

The best predictors of preterm labor in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on transvaginal ultrasound.

Related Pearl: Tocolytic agents

Drugs Examples
Calcium channel blockers
Nifedipine
Nicardipine
Verapamil
Competitive inhibition to calcium ion
 Magnesium sulfate
Cyclo-oxygenase inhibitors
Indomethacin
Sulindac
Beta mimetics
Terbutaline
Ritodrine
Isoxsuprine
Oxytocin Antagonists
Atosiban
Nitric oxide (NO) Donors
  Glyceryl trinitrate (GTN)

questions.text:
Which of the following parameters are included in the modified Biophysical profile score?
  1. Oxytocin challenge test
  2. Contraction stress test
  3. Amniotic fluid index
  4. Vibroacoustic nonstress test
  5. Amniotic fluid volume
questions.solution:
Vibroacoustic nonstress test/Nonstress test (NST) and Amniotic fluid index (AFI) (options 3 and 4) are included in the modified biophysical score.

Biophysical profile (BPP)/Manning score provides a means of accessing fetal health. Involves the measurement of the following: (Mnemonic: BATMaN)

  • B-Breathing 
  • A-Amniotic fluid volume (AFV)
  • T-Tone of fetus
  • M-Movements of fetus
  • N-Non Stress Test (NST)

Normal score: >=8 (with normal AFV). The maximum score is 10.

Abnormal scores:

  • 8/10 with decreased AFV: suspicion of chronic fetal asphyxia
  • 6/10: Possible fetal asphyxia
  • 4/10: Probable fetal asphyxia
  • 0-2/10: Almost certain fetal asphyxia

Maternal sedatives and narcotics can significantly lower the score.

The biophysical profile was modified to includes two parameters- the biweekly vibroacoustic nonstress test or Nonstress test and the AFI. 

The nonstress test describes fetal heart rate acceleration in response to fetal movements, using a Doppler to detect fetal heart rate acceleration. Fetal movements are recorded as perceived by the mother. Acoustic stimula­tion nonstress test is one in which a loud external sound is used to startle the fetus and provoke heart rate accelerations.

  • Normal modified BPP: Reactive nonstress test with AFI>5cm
  • Abnormal modified BPP: nonreactive nonstress test or AFI <5 cm 

Oxytocin challenge test (Contraction stress test): The fetal heart rate and uterine contrac­tions are recorded simultaneously with an external monitor. If at least three spontaneous contractions of 40 seconds or longer are present in 10 minutes, uterine stimulation is not required. If required, it can be done with iv oxytocin or nipple stimulation.

A positive test(abnormal) is uniform repetitive late fetal heart rate decelerations, which could indicate uteroplacental insufficiency. A negative test would show no late or significant variable decelerations.

The nonstress test is a test of fetal condition, while the contraction stress test is a test of uteroplacental function.

Contraindications of contraction stress testing:

  • Compromised fetus
  • Previous history of cesarean section
  • Complications likely to produce preterm labor
  • Antepartum hemorrhage
  • Multiple pregnancies

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is used for:

choices.text: Delivery of occipitotransverse position in platypelloid pelvis
Delivery of after coming head in breech delivery
Outlet forceps used to provide traction force

questions.solution:
The image shows Wrigley's forceps, which is an outlet forceps used to provide traction force.

 Wrigley's forceps are used exclusively in outlet forceps operations for the extraction of the head. It is used to provide traction force. The instrument is light and short due to a reduction in the length of the shanks and handles. It has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve. Outlet forceps are used when:

  • the fetal scalp is visible without separating the labia
  • the fetal skull has reached the pelvic floor, at or on the perineum
  • the sagittal suture is in the anteroposterior diameter or right or left occiput anterior or posterior position (rotation does not exceed 45°)

 

Other options:

Option A: Kielland forceps are used in correcting asynctilism.

Option B: Barton forceps are used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.

Option C: Piper forceps have a distinct perineal curve and allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: A young woman, who was diagnosed with threatened abortion was referred to you from the peripheral hospital for an USG (Ultrasonography). Examination of this patient would reveal:

choices.text: Closed cervical os with absent fetal cardiac activity on USG
Closed cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG
Dilated cervical os with absent fetal cardiac activity on USG
Dilated cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG

questions.solution:
Examination of a patient diagnosed with threatened abortion would reveal closed cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG.

In threatened miscarriage, the process of miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • Uterus and cervix feel soft
  • Transvaginal Ultrasonography shows well-formed gestation ring indicating healthy fetus with fetal cardiac activity.

Abortion is the expulsion or extraction from the mother of an embryo or fetus weighing 500 g or less when it is not capable of independent survival.

Classification of abortion:

Other options:

Option A: In missed abortion, the fetus is dead and is retained inside the uterus for a variable period. Here closed cervical os with absent fetal cardiac activity on USG can be seen.

Option C: In incomplete abortion, entire products of conception are not expelled, instead, a part of it is left inside the uterine cavity. Here dilated cervical os with absent fetal cardiac activity on USG can be seen.

Option D: In inevitable abortion, the changes have progressed to a state from where continuation of pregnancy is impossible. Here dilated cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG can be seen.

Related Pearl: Clinical classification of Spontaneous Abortion

Clinical type Description/ Clinical picture Cervical os  USG
Threatened 

bloody vaginal discharge or bleeding appears through a closed cervical os.

 Closed 

The gestational sac/ pseudo-gestational sac
Inevitable 

A gush of vaginal fluid, bleeding, cramping, or fever.

 Gross rupture of the membranes along with cervical dilatation Low lying sac with oligohydramnios
Incomplete 

Bleeding that follows partial or complete placental separation and dilation of the cervical os.

 Cervix dilated Retained products 
Complete 

The expulsion of the entire pregnancy has completed before the woman presents to the hospital

A history of heavy bleeding, cramping, and passage of tissue or a fetus is common

 Cervical os closed

Minimally thickened endometrium without a gestational sac
Missed /early pregnancy failure or loss

Dead products of conception that were retained for days, weeks or even months in the uterus with a closed cervical os

Defined currently based on results of serial serum β-hCG assays and transvaginal sonography

 Cervical os closed

A large anechoic sac consistent with an anembryonic gestation
Septic 

1 to 2 percent of women with threatened or incomplete miscarriage develops a pelvic infection and sepsis syndrome

questions.text: A primigravida woman underwent a normal vaginal delivery at her home following which she presented with a perineal tear as shown below. Identify the grade of perineal tear:
questions.solution:
The image showing a tear in the vaginal mucosa, perineal muscles, and more than 50% of the external anal sphincter is suggestive of a grade 3b perineal tear.

Perineal tears are common in primigravida women undergoing vaginal delivery.

The first-degree tears do not require repairs but suturing of laceration prevents the vaginal orifice from becoming patulous. Second-degree tears must be immediately sutured after the delivery of the placenta to prevent the weakening of the pelvic floor and genital prolapse. 

Third and fourth-degree tears must be efficiently repaired to prevent flatus and faecal incontinence. Such tears are common in median episiotomies, incorrect usage of forceps in a persistent occipitoposterior positioned fetus, delivery of aftercoming of breech, precipitate labour and delivery of macrosomic babies.

The best time for repair of a complete perineal tear is within 24 hours of the injury. If not done within 24hrs, it is preferably done 3-6 months after delivery. If the perineal tear is untreated for more than 6 months, dense scar tissue forms and making the surgery difficult. 

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primi developed fever and pruritic rashes one day after a full-term normal vaginal delivery. A diagnosis of varicella infection was made. How should the neonate be managed?

choices.text: Acyclovir therapy should be started immediately

questions.solution:
Passive immunization with Varicella-Zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) is administered to neonates whose mothers develop a varicella-zoster rash from five days before delivery up to two days after delivery.

If the fetus or neonate is exposed to active varicella infection just before or during delivery, they may develop a disseminated visceral and central nervous system disease, which can be fatal. Neonates born before or after this time are not at risk of severe neonatal chickenpox, and do not require passive immunization.

VZIG may not prevent infection, but reduces the severity of neonatal infection. Monitoring of the neonate should be prolonged to 28 days, as VZIG may prolong the incubation period.

If signs of neonatal infection develop despite VZIG, the neonate should be treated with acyclovir. 

Primary varicella infection presents with flu-like symptoms, followed by a pruritic vesicular rash. The fetus may develop congenital varicella syndrome if infection occurs in the first half of pregnancy, the highest risk is between 13 and 20 weeks. Features of congenital varicella syndrome include:

  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cerebral cortical atrophy
  • Growth restriction
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Cicatricial skin lesions

Pregnant women who are exposed to varicella and are susceptible should be given VZIG. Infected women usually require only supportive care, but those who require intravenous (IV) fluids and or develop pneumonia should be hospitalized. Intravenous acyclovir therapy is given to women requiring hospitalization.

questions.text: A type 1 diabetic mother is on magnesium sulfate infusion post-cesarean section for preeclampsia. She develops delirium and is drowsy. She has a respiratory rate of 10/min, random blood glucose level of 240 mg/dL, oliguria, and bilaterally absent knee reflex. What is the cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and examination finding of bilaterally absent knee reflex following magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) administration for preeclampsia suggest the cause of her condition to be magnesium sulfate toxicity. 

MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. It can also be used as a tocolytic to stop preterm labor. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4–7 mEq/L. 

Patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • Decreased respiratory rate <12/min
  • Urine output <30 mL/h
  • Chest pain and heart block 
  • Visual changes, flushing, muscle paralysis, and drowsiness

Measurement of serum magnesium levels is indicated to monitor magnesium toxicity if serum creatinine >1.0 mg/dL.

Management of magnesium toxicity is as follows:

  • Stop magnesium therapy
  • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
  • Intravenous injection of calcium gluconate 10 mL (10% solution) 

The two commonly used MgSO4 regimens are described below: 

Regimen

Loading Dose

Maintenance Dose

Intramuscular (Pritchard)

4 g (20% solution) IV over 3–5 minutes, followed by 10 g (50%) deep IM (5 g in each buttock)

5 g (50%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock

Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai)

4 g IV slow over 15–20 minute

1–2 g/h IV infusion

Repeated/maintenance dose IM injections of magnesium sulfate are continued only under the following conditions:

  • The patellar reflex is present
  • Respiration is not depressed
  • Urine output >30 mL/h

Other options:

Option B: Pregnant women with diabetic ketoacidosis present with hyperventilation (Kussmaul breathing) and their blood glucose level is around 380 mg/dL.

Option C: Eclampsia patients present with generalized tonic-clonic convulsions.

Option D: Diabetes insipidus patients present with polyuria and polydipsia.

questions.text: During genetic counseling, a pregnant woman states that both she and her husband have sickle cell trait. You offer the option of chorionic villus sampling for prenatal diagnosis. What is the best time to perform this procedure?
questions.solution:
The best time to perform chorionic villous sampling is 11-13 weeks.

Chorionic villus sampling:
Study material

Chorionic villi from trophoblastic cells

Time

10 to 13 weeks (transcervically)

10 weeks to term (transabdominally)

Indications

To detect chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome.

To detect inborn errors of metabolism like phenylketonuria.

For DNA analysis in hemoglobinopathies, thalassemia, and sickle cell anemia.
Complications

Abortion (CVS> Amniocentesis)

Limb reduction defects and oro-mandibular defects (when done before 10 weeks)
Drawback

Not suitable for the detection of neural tube defects.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman conceived after being treated for infertility. Her USG scan is given below. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the twin peak sign which is seen in dichorionic diamniotic twins. This is also known as the lambda sign or delta sign.

In dichorionic twins, the intervening membrane between the twins has 4 layers i.e. 2 chorions and 2 amnions. The placenta protrudes from the base to the space between the 2 amnion layers. This gives rise to the twin peak sign i.e. triangle with the base at placenta and apex in the intervening membrane.

 

Sonographic assessment of dichorionicity is done by observing the following:

  • Number of placental masses - 2
  • Presence of intervening membrane - twin peak or lambda or delta sign
  • Thickness of intervening membranes ≥ 2mm

The best time of delivery of dichorionic diamniotic twins is 38 weeks.

questions.text: A grand multipara had continuous, moderate vaginal bleeding immediately after delivery. What could be the most probable cause of bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum haemorrhage in a grand multipara.

Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. Contraction helps to arrest bleeding from vessels at the placental implantation site.

Types of PPH:

  1. Primary/early: Haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. Uterine atony is the most common cause of primary PPH.
  2. Secondary/late: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Retained placenta is the most common cause.

The risk factors for atonic uterus include:

  1. Primiparity or grand multiparity
  2. Previous PPH
  3. Overdistended uterus as in multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, macrosomia
  4. Precipitate labour
  5. Prolonged labour
  6. Uterine malformations
  7. Uterine fibroid
  8. Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin
  9. Placental abnormalities like placenta previa, accreta, increta, percreta, or abruptio placenta
  10. Obesity
  11. Age >40 years

Note: Uterine inversion occurs rarely and causes secondary PPH.

questions.text: Suitable cases for expectant management in case of placenta previa include all except:
questions.solution:
The duration of pregnancy must be less than 37 weeks for expectant management which was advocated by McAfee and Johnson. 

The aim of conservative management is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health.

Prerequisites:

  • Availability of blood for transfusion 
  • Facilities for cesarean section available 

Selection of cases for expectant management for placenta previa: 

  1. Mother is hemodynamically stable (Hb >10 g% and/or hematocrit > 30%) 
  2. Duration of pregnancy <37 weeks 
  3. No active vaginal bleeding 
  4. Fetus normal on USG and reactive on CTG

Conduct of expectant treatment: 

  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity 
  • Bed rest or pelvic rest
  • Periodic monitoring of mother for bleeding pv
  • Fetal surveillance with USG  
  • Tocolytics if contractions are present
  • Anti-D to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women.

questions.text: A primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation was admitted for management of preterm labour. Which of the following tocolytics would be preferred for this?
questions.solution:
Nifedipine is the preferred tocolytic as it has minimum maternal side effects.

According to ACOG guidelines, the use of tocolytics in preterm labour does not prolong gestation but may delay delivery upto 48 hours. Hence, short-term therapy with tocolytics is given for 1-3 days to delay labour for the action of corticosteroid therapy or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). 

Tocolytics used in preterm labour and their side effects:

Tocolytics Maternal side effects Fetal/ neonatal side effects

Beta-adrenergic agonists:

  • Ritodrine
  • Terbutaline
  • Isoxsuprine

Headache, palpitations, tachycardia, hypotension, pulmonary edema, cardiac failure, ARDS

Fetal heart failure, intrauterine death

Neonatal hypoglycemia, intraventricular haemorrhage

Calcium channel blockers:

  • Nifedipine
  • Nicardipine
  • Verapamil
 Hypotension, headache, flushing, nausea -

Oxytocin antagonists:

  • Atosiban

(not approved for use in India)

Magnesium sulphate Flushing, perspiration, headache, muscle weakness, respiratory paralysis Neonatal cardiac arrest, lethargy, hypotonia, respiratory depression

COX inhibitors:

  • Indomethacin
  • Sulindac

questions.text: A woman with 6 weeks of amenorrhea had a positive urine pregnancy test. The following finding was seen on transabdominal USG. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given USG image shows an empty gestational sac which is seen in missed abortion before 12 weeks. At this gestational age,  the entire ovum is covered by the chorionic villi giving rise to the empty gestational sac.

If this condition occurs beyond 12 weeks of gestation, a dead fetus is seen on USG. This is not preceded by any warning signs and the fetus is not expelled outside spontaneously.

questions.text: The following instrument is used to augment labour in a 28-year-old primigravida via low rupture of membranes. Identify this instrument.
questions.solution:
The given instrument is Kocher's artery forceps and is identified by the presence of a single tooth at the tip.

Kocher's artery forceps are used to achieve hemostasis by holding bleeding vessels. They are also used in low rupture of membranes to augment labour or for the surgical induction of labour. 

The difference between artery forceps and needle holders is in the edge and smoothness of corrugations. Artery forceps have smooth edges and single lined corrugations whereas, needle holders have rough edges and crossed lines forming square to diamond shaped corrugations.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman in labor is referred to a tertiary care center. On PV examination, the resident notes that the fetus is in brow presentation, and the largest diameter of the fetal skull is engaged. Identify this diameter.
questions.solution:
In brow presentation, the mentovertical diameter is engaged which is the longest diameter of the fetal skull. Normally, it measures 14 cm. 

The mentovertical diameter extends from the midpoint of the chin to the highest point on the sagittal suture.

Engaging diameters of the fetal skull vary with the attitude of the fetal head as given below:

Diameters Attitude of the head
Suboccipitobregmatic Complete flexion
Suboccipito-frontal Incomplete flexion
Occipitofrontal Marked deflexion
Mento-vertical Partial extension
Submentovertical Incomplete extension
Submentobregmatic Complete extension

Related Pearl: Fetal Skull Dimensions

Note: 

Shortest diameters of fetal skull: Bimastoid - 7.5 cm (doesn't engage) < Bitemporal - 8 cm

Longest diameter of fetal skull: Mentovertical 14 cm > Submentovertical / occipitofrontal - 11.5cm

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman is diagnosed to have cervical cancer. MRI and PET-CT imaging reveal tumour extension up to the pelvic wall and involvement of the para-aortic lymph nodes. It also shows features suggestive of hydronephrosis. Which stage is it according to the FIGO staging of cervical cancer?

PET-CT - Positron Emission Tomography/Computed Tomography
FIGO - International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics
questions.solution:
Cervical cancer involving the para-aortic lymph nodes is classified as Stage III C2 according to FIGO staging.

Cervical cancer is the most common gynecological cancer. The FIGO staging uses clinical, radiological, or pathological findings to stage cervical cancer from Stage I to IV.

Stage III cervical carcinoma involves the lower 1/3rd of the vagina, with or without pelvic wall extension, hydronephrosis, and lymph node involvement. It is further staged as follows:

  • Stage III A: Lower 1/3rd of the vagina involvement, no pelvic wall extension
  • Stage III B: Pelvic wall involvement with or without hydronephrosis or a non-functioning kidney
  • Stage III C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or paraaortic lymph nodes
    • Stage III C1: Metastasis to pelvic lymph node only
    • Stage III C2: Metastasis to para-aortic lymph nodes

Note: If the carcinoma had extended beyond the true pelvis, involving adjacent pelvic organs like the bladder or rectum, it would've been classified as Stage IV A.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

Related Pearl: General treatment for primary invasive cervical carcinoma

Stages Fertility preserved Fertility not preserved
IA1 Cervical conization Simple hysterectomy
IA1 (LVSI) Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Modified radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
IA2

1. Cervical conization with extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy

2. Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

 Modified Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

IB1

Some IB2, IIA1

 Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or)chemoradiation Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or) chemoradiation
Bulky IB3, IIA2 Chemoradiation
IIB to IVA Chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration 
IVB Palliative chemotherapy or palliative radiotherapy or supportive care

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman presents with irregular bleeding. Endometrial biopsy revealed endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. How would you consider treating this patient?
questions.solution:
Progesterone therapy such as norethisterone followed by endometrial biopsy every 3 to 6 months is the best treatment in the case of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia.

Endometrial hyperplasia is defined as endometrial thickening with the proliferation of irregularly sized and shaped glands and an increased gland-to-stroma ratio. It is a pre-malignant lesion for endometrial carcinoma.

WHO Classification of endometrial hyperplasia based on histology:

  • Simple without atypia: there is an increase in number of glands but the architecture is not compromised. 
  • Simple with atypia: simple hyperplasia with features of nuclear atypia (variation in nuclear shape, size, and prominent nucleoli)
  • Complex without atypia: glands are markedly crowded and irregular
  • Complex with atypia: complex hyperplasia with atypical nuclear features. 

However, there is generally no clear histological distinction between the above mentioned classification, so endometrial hyperplasia is classified into hyperplasia without atypia and atypical hyperplasia/endometrioid intraepithelial neoplasia. 

Type of hyperplasia Risk of progression to cancer
Simple without atypia 1%
Complex without atypia 3%
Simple with atypia 8%
Complex with atypia 29%

Management of Endometrial hyperplasia:

1) Hyperplasia without atypia:

Intrauterine or continuous oral progesterone. Levonorgestrel releasing intrauterine system is preferred due to its lower side effect profile, higher rate of disease resolution. Oral progesterone can be given in the form of medroxyprogesterone acetate 10-20 mg/day. 

Endometrial surveillance in the form of biopsy should be performed at 6-month intervals. At least 2 consecutive negative biopsies should be obtained. Those at high risk (body mass index of more than 35, treated with oral progesterone) should be advised annual follow-up. 

2) Atypical hyperplasia:

Total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is suggested in those with atypical hyperplasia due to the risk of progression to malignancy. 

Premenopausal women who want to preserve their fertility should be counseled regarding the risk of progression to cancer. Once fertility is no longer required, then hysterectomy should be offered. 

Those who refuse hysterectomy should have routine endometrial biopsies every 3 months until 2 consecutive negative biopsies are obtained.

questions.text: A young nulliparous female who desires pregnancy comes to you with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding. On palpation, an abdominal mass corresponding to 14 weeks of gestation is felt. The mass is found to be a subserosal pedunculated fibroid on imaging. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice in this nulliparous female with subserosal pedunculated fibroid is myomectomy. Myomectomy is indicated if the uterus size corresponds to more than 12 weeks of gestation and the patient desires pregnancy.

Myomectomy refers to the removal of fibroids and preserving the uterus. It is indicated in fibroids which present with the following 

  • Persistent uterine bleeding despite medical therapy
  • Excessive pain or pressure symptoms
  • Size > 12 weeks, patient desirous to have a baby
  • Unexplained infertility with distortion of the uterine cavity due to fibroid
  • Recurrent pregnancy wastage due to fibroid
  • Rapid growth during follow up
  • Subserous pedunculated fibroid

Myomectomy can be performed by laparoscopy, hysteroscopy, or laparotomy. It is contraindicated in patients with an infected fibroid, pelvic or endometrial tuberculosis, suspected malignancy, and growth in post-menopausal and multiparous women where hysterectomy can be the safe definitive management.

Fibroids are benign estrogen dependant tumors of the uterine smooth muscles and connective tissue. 

Management of uterine fibroids in asymptomatic patients includes observation with regular follow-up regardless of the size of the fibroid. Surgery is indicated in cornual fibroids if it causes infertility or pedunculated fibroids (due to the risk of torsion). 

In symptomatic patients, medical therapy is done to shrink the fibroid. It acts as a preoperative adjunct. Surgical methods such as myomectomy, laparoscopic myolysis, hysterectomy, and endometrial ablation are tried for patients with persistent symptoms despite conservative management. Hysterectomy is done in postmenopausal women and in multiparous women who have completed their families or are not desirous of childbirth.

Related Pearl: Myomectomy

Myomectomy

  • Retains uterus and hence preserves childbearing function.
  • Effective for heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure.
  • Disadvantage - Formation of new clones of abnormal myocytes.
  • Hysteroscopic myomectomy is the procedure of choice for removing intracavitary myomas.
  • Vaginal myomectomy-For a fibroid prolapses through the cervix.

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility. A cornual fibroid (blocking the tube) and submucous fibroid (habitual abortions).
  • Chances of torsion. 
  • Urinary tract infection. A fibroid pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy and requiring surgery.
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text:
Match the following patients with Uterine prolapse with their best treatment option.
          Age/condition       Management
  1. Nulliparous women with desire for future pregnancy
  2. 45-year-old with no desire for menstruation/pregnancy
  3. 30-year-old in puerperial period
  4. 38-year-old with family complete but desires for menstruation.
  1. Fothergill's operation
  2. Cervicopexy
  3. Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair
  4.  Ring pessary
questions.solution:
Option C is correct. 

          Age/condition       Management

1) Nulliparous women with a desire for future pregnancy

ii.  Cervicopexy

2) 45-year-old with no desire for menstruation/pregnancy

iii.  Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

3) 30-year-old in puerperial period

 iv.  Ring pessary 

4) 38-year-old with family complete but desires for menstruation.

i.  Fothergill's operation

Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse for those who wish to retain menstrual and child-bearing function. Mackenrodt’s and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened, by using nylon or Dacron tapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include abdominal wall cervicopexy, Shirodkar’s sling operation, Khanna’s abdominal sling operation, Virkud's sling operation, and Joshi's sling operation.

Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the ideal management of genital prolapse in women >40 years of age, those who have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.

A ring pessary is used for patients who cannot be surgically managed, such as pregnant patients, patients in puerperium, and very elderly women unfit for surgery. It is used in adjunct with pelvic floor physiotherapy. Pessaries provide mechanical support to the pelvic organs. The first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained is to ask the patient to perform Valsalva's manoeuvre or cough and see if the pessary is in place. After being placed, they need to be changed every 3 months. 

Fothergill's repair also known as Manchester's operation is suitable for women under 40 years who are desirous of retaining their menstrual and reproductive functions. It involves anterior colporrhaphy with amputation of the cervix. The mackenrodt ligaments are sutured in the front of the cervix and colpoperineorrhaphy is done. It increases the risk of cervical incompetence leading to recurrent abortions and preterm deliveries. Shirodkar's modification of Fothergill's repair avoids cervical amputation, hence subsequent pregnancy complications are avoided.  

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Congenital/ Nulliparous (young) uterine prolapse: Sling/ cervicopexy

Uterovaginal uterine prolapse:

Age/condition Desire for pregnancy Desire for menstruation Surgery
<40 No Yes Fothergill's operation
>40 No No  Ward Mayo's vaginal hysterectomy
>60(medically unfit for hysterectomy)        -      - Le Forts repair
Prolapse during pregnancy /puerperium     -       - Ring Pessary

Related Pearl: Degrees of vault prolapse

  • First degree: The vaginal apex is visible at the introitus
  • Second degree: The vault protrudes through the introitus
  • Third degree: The entire vagina is outside the introitus

2. Turner's syndrome b.Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries
3. Swyer’s Syndrome c. Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

questions.text: A middle-aged woman complains of urine dribbling from the vagina. On further examination and investigation, she is diagnosed with a vesicovaginal fistula. Which of the following is false about the management of her condition?

choices.text: Latzko procedure is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula, caused by cancer cervix
Following a failed attempt, a second attempt can be made after 4 weeks
Continous bladder drainage required for 14 days postoperatively
Sexual abstinence for 3 months is advised after the surgery

questions.solution:
In case the fistula repair fails, a second attempt is made only after 3 months.

Vesicovaginal fistula(VVF) is a type of genital fistula, which is an abnormal communication between the genital tract and the urinary tract. It occurs mostly due to obstetric injuries such as prolonged labor, and instrumental or manipulative deliveries. Patients present with true incontinence characterized by constant dribbling of urine.

Small fistulas due to difficult childbirth can heal spontaneously. In the case of an established fistula, it is better to wait for about 3 months for all tissue inflammation to subside, before surgery is undertaken. Most vesicovaginal fistulas are repaired per vaginally. The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure: It is done by denudation of vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges and approximation of raw surface with absorbable sutures. This technique is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula that is caused by cancer cervix (Option A). It can lead to narrowing of the vagina or vaginal atresia. Fistula located at the vaginal vault, post hysterectomy is the most difficult to treat, this technique is suited for such cases.
  • Chassar-Moir technique: Here, the vagina and bladder are separated and sutured into two layers taking care to avoid tension and overlapping suture lines. 
  • Ureteric implantation into the sigmoid colon in case previous surgeries fail.

Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days (Option C) along with antibiotics is recommended. Vaginal or speculum examination and intercourse are not advised for 3 months after surgery (Option D). Avoiding pregnancy for a year is also recommended. A cesarean section is usually done for future pregnancies.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology Mostly obstetric causes mostly gynecological surgeries
Clinical Continuous dribbling of urine—no micturition Continuous dribbling of urine but can also micturate
Methylene swab test Swab stains with methylene blue   Swab stains with urine—but not with methylene blue
IVP Normal Hydronephrosis presents on the affected side

The methylene blue 3 swab test:

Procedure:

A catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle and one just above the introitus.

50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a catheter.

Results:

  • Uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula

Related Pearl: Methylene blue - 3 swab test

Procedure:

A catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three (or four) sterile cotton swabs.

50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a catheter.

Results:

  • Upper swabs get wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Upper swabs get stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lower swabs get stained - the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula.

questions.text:
A middle-aged woman, who is on the workup for infertility and menstrual irregularities underwent hysterosalpingography(HSG ). What features on HSG would have helped the doctor to make a diagnosis of genital tuberculosis?

1- Rigid non-peristaltic pipe-like tube.
2- Wedge-shaped defect at the uterine isthmus.
3- Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx.
4- Golf club appearance in the ampullary portion of the fallopian tube.
questions.solution:
A wedge shaped defect at the uterine isthmus is seen in patients with cesarean section history with a uterine scar and not in genital tuberculosis.

Hysterosalpingography features of genital tuberculosis(tubercular salpingitis) are:

  • Rigid non-peristaltic pipe-like tube (Lead pipe appearance)
  • Beading and variation in filling defect
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx
  • Golf club appearance with slight or moderate dilatation of the ampullary portion of the fallopian tube.
  • Rosette type appearance secondary to multiple small diverticular like out pouching surrounding the ampulla produced by caseous ulceration.

Tuberculous tubes:

Note : HSG should not be performed in a suspected case of genital tuberculosis as it causes dissemination of the infection. This further increases the damage to the fallopian tubes.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with dysmenorrhoea, menorrhagia, and infertility. After ruling out other possible causes, the gynecologist suspects endometriosis. Which of the following investigations will be most helpful in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the investigation that will be most helpful in the diagnosis is laparoscopy.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. The patient usually presents with symptoms of abdominal pain, dyspareunia, dysmenorrhea, and infertility. The presence of puckered spots in the posterior fornix is pathognomonic of endometriosis. It is an estrogen-dependent disease of the childbearing age group. The most common site of occurrence is the ovary, followed by the pouch of Douglas.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis is visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. Typically, there are small black dots, the so-called powder burns/tattooing seen on the uterosacral ligaments and pouch of Douglas. 

Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis:

  • To detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis.
  • Locate the site of endometriosis and staging.
  • To take biopsy
  • To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation, removal.

Other investigations:

  • CA-125 levels are raised in endometriosis.
  • Monocyte chemotactic protein (MCP-1) levels are raised in the peritoneal fluid of women with endometriosis.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound reveals an echo-free cyst, low level echoes or clumps of high-density level echoes representing clots.

The image below shows powder burns/tattooing appearance of endometriosis on diagnostic laparoscopy.

Other options:

Option A: Hysteroscopy and Endometrial Biopsy: These evaluate conditions within the uterine cavity, such as polyps or hyperplasia, but endometriosis involves ectopic endometrial tissue outside the uterus, making this investigation unhelpful for its diagnosis.  

Option B: Transvaginal Ultrasound (TVUS): While TVUS can detect ovarian endometriomas, it cannot reliably identify peritoneal or deep infiltrating endometriosis, limiting its utility in providing a comprehensive diagnosis.  

Option C: Hysterosalpingography (HSG): This test is primarily used to assess tubal patency and uterine contour in infertility workups but does not provide direct visualization of endometrial implants, making it unsuitable for diagnosing endometriosis.  

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: An incidental ovarian mass is found when evaluating a 19-year-old girl for kidney stones. The mass is removed and its contents are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient with an asymptomatic ovarian mass consisting hair, bone, and sebaceous material is a mature teratoma. 

Teratomas are germ cell tumors. They contain embryonic tissues leading to the differentiation of cells along these pathways. There are three classes of teratomas:

  • Mature (benign) teratomas (eg: Dermoid cyst)
  • Immature (essentially malignant) teratomas (eg: solid teratoma)
  • Monodermal (highly specialized) tumors (eg: Struma ovarii)

Mature cystic teratoma, also known as dermoid cysts are unilocular in structure and have a smooth surface. They usually are lined by squamous epithelium with hair follicles leading to the formation of sebaceous material and hair. Other structures like teeth, bone, cartilage, thyroid tissue, and mucous membranes can also be found. 

Most patients are asymptomatic. Some patients may have symptoms because of the mass size of the teratoma. In other patients, ovarian teratomas can result in torsion of the ovary. Other rare complications include rupture of the cyst and spillage of contents into the abdominal cavity. 

Treatment of mature teratomas involves excision in order to prevent complications. Otherwise, mature teratomas are generally innocent. 

Other options: 

Option A - Immature teratomas such as solid teratomas of the ovary are solid and trabeculated. They also contain cartilage, bone, hair, and sebaceous material. There is no structural order. They are generally malignant. Grossly, they have a smooth external surface and are solid on sectioning. There may be areas of necrosis or hemorrhage. 

The following image shows both mature (left) and immature teratomas (right). 

Option C - Struma ovarii is a type of highly specialized teratoma that contains only thyroid tissue. If it is functioning, it may lead to hyperthyroidism. 

Option D - Granulosa cell tumors arise from the sex cords of the gonads. They are solid and generally produce estrogen. They can cause precocious puberty in children, hyperestrogenism in adults, and post-menopausal bleeding. They vary in appearance and range from microscopic to large, solid and cystic, encapsulated masses. If hormonally active, they may be yellow due to intracellular lipids.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

questions.text: You are examining an 18-year-old woman and it appears she has mature adult breasts. What is the Tanner stage of breast development in her?
questions.solution: The Tanner staging of the breast, in case of mature adult breast, is denoted as B5.

questions.text: According to DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs, uterosacral ligaments belong to which level of pelvic support?
questions.solution:
According to DeLancey, the uterosacral ligaments and cardinal ligaments belong to level 1.

This dense visceral connective tissue complex maintains the vaginal length and horizontal axis. It allows the vagina to be supported by the levator plate and positions the cervix just superior to the level of the ischial spines. Defects in this support complex may lead to apical prolapse.

Level I support suspends the proximal vagina. Level II support attaches the midvagina along its length to the arcus tendineus fascia. Level III support results from the fusion of the distal vagina with adjacent structures. 

Pubococcygeus is the deepest part of the levator ani muscle. Injury to it can cause enterocele, cystocele, and urethral descent. 

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum
