questions.text: The absence of the SRY gene results in which of the following?

choices.text: Development of ovaries and Mullerian system

questions.solution:
The absence of the SRY gene results in the development of the ovaries and the Mullerian system.

In this situation, the gonads will develop into ovaries and the Mullerian duct will differentiate into the uterus, fallopian tubes, and the upper part of the vagina. The master gene responsible for this is the WNT4 gene.

The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome, which has a sex-determining region called the SRY gene.

If the Y chromosome is present, the protein called testis determining factor produced by the SRY gene will lead to the development of testis as the gonads. The Sertoli cells of the testis will then produce Müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS; also known as Anti-Müllerian hormone, AMH) that will cause the Müllerian ducts to regress.

Functions of SRY and WNT4:

SRY gene WNT4 gene

Development of the medullary/testes cords

The disappearance of medullary/testes cords

Formation of the tunica albuginea

Failure of formation of tunica albuginea

Failure of development of cortical/ovarian cords 

 Development of ovaries with typical cortical cords

Related Pearl: Sexual Differentiation

questions.text: A young female patient is undergoing evaluation for infertility and is posted for a hysterosalpingogram. Which of the following is not a contraindication for hysterosalpingography?
questions.solution:
All of the following are contraindications for hysterosalpingography (HSG) except option C. Uterine synechiae is an indication for HSG.

Contraindications for HSG:

  • Presence of genital tract infection and bleeding
  • Genital Tuberculosis, due to the risk of spreading infection.
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Allergy to the dye
  • Premenstrual phase
    • If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged.
    • Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye, at the cornual end.
    • There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is an imaging technique used for visualization of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by the injection of a radiopaque dye. 

It is best performed between day 5 and day 10 of the menstrual cycle.

10-15ml of the dye is injected using a Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter. If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

It is used to detect:

  • Tubal patency
  • Uterine anomalies
  • Uterine polyps
  • Uterine synechiae
  • Feasibility of tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct

Surrogacy for treatment of infertility 

Vaginal hypoplasia is surgically corrected at the time of marriage

 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any   Uterine rupture, abortions, risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct Metroplasty (Resection of membrane and fundal recombination) Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation 
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part fused where as upper part unfused Metroplasty in selected cases  Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 

Diminished fertility, Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation

 
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (cockscomb cervix)   Ectopic pregnancy,  cervical incompetance,  clear cell adenocarcinoma of vagina and cervix 

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman suffers from emotional lability, fatigue, bloating, headache, sleeplessness, and breast tenderness about 10 days prior to her menses. These symptoms get relieved once she menstruates. All of the following are recommended in the management of this condition except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of Premenstrual syndrome (PMS). All the above-mentioned measures are recommended in the management of PMS except caffeine. Foods and beverages rich in sugar and caffeine can aggravate premenstrual symptoms in some women and are generally avoided. 

Premenstrual syndrome can be managed by dietary changes and lifestyle modifications like yoga, exercises and relaxation activities. Pharmacological therapy includes the usage of primrose oil, vitamin B1, vitamin B6, vitamin E, calcium and magnesium supplements.

Symptoms can be alleviated by the use of prostaglandin inhibitors (ibuprofen and naproxen ), Selective Serotonin Reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) like fluoxetine, GABA antagonists and anxiolytics such as alprazolam. Danazol, bromocriptine and GnRH analogues can be used to reduce breast pain. OCPs with spironolactone and Mirena IUCD can also be used.

Premenstrual Syndrome (PMS) is a symptom complex associated with ovulatory cycles. It occurs 7 to 14 days prior to menstruation and spontaneously resolves after menses. It occurs in the luteal phase of the cycle. When this symptom complex causes significant impairment, a diagnosis of premenstrual dysphoric disorder(PMDD) is made according to DSM-5.

Symptoms include

  • Pain:- Headache, breast pain, abdominal cramps, muscle stiffness, backache and generalized body ache.
  • Water retention:- Breast volume increase, bloating and weight gain.
  • Behavioural changes:- Low performance, difficulty in concentration, irritability, depression, forgetfulness, low judgement, anxiety, loneliness, feeling like crying, hostility, increased appetite and cravings and sleeplessness.
  • Autonomic changes:- Dizziness, faintness, nausea, vomiting and hot flushes.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is being evaluated for bleeding per vagina. She attained menopause at the age of 47. Which of the following is least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, ovarian follicular cysts are least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding.

 Ovarian follicular cysts are usually asymptomatic unless they rupture, hemorrhage, or the ovary undergoes torsion which would manifest as an acute abdomen. They occur when there is the failure of absorption of fluid in an incompletely developed follicle or anovulation. 

Postmenopausal bleeding is diagnosed when there is bleeding per vagina after 6 months of amenorrhoea after the age of 40 (menopausal age). 

Causes of postmenopausal bleeding include: 

  • Genital tract trauma (Option A)
  • Cervical erosion, inflammation, polyp, ulcer, or cervical carcinoma.
  • Uterus - endometritis, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma (Option C), polyp, or sarcoma
  • Fallopian tube malignancy
  • Ovarian tumors such as Brenner tumor, granulosa cell tumor (Option D)
  • Hypertension and blood dyscrasia
  • Urinary tract trauma, bladder carcinoma
  • Hemorrhoid, anal fissures, and rectal cancers confused as bleeding per vagina
  • Use of estrogens as hormone replacement therapy, tamoxifen.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

questions.text: In a woman diagnosed with infertility, which of the following antihormonal substance can be used to induce ovulation?
questions.solution:
Clomiphene citrate is an antihormonal substance used to induce ovulation in a patient diagnosed with infertility. Ovulation can be induced by giving clomiphene citrate 50 mg daily, starting from day 2 to day 6 of the menstrual cycle for 5 days.

Related Pearl: Management of female infertility for different causes are as follows

Etiology Investigations Management  
Tubal cause
  • Hysterosalpingography or sonosalpingography
  • Falloscopy
  • Salpingography
  • Laparoscopic chromotubation
  • Laparoscopic adhesiolysis
  • Tuboplasty
  • Hysteroscopic cannulation and balloonplasty
  • If all the above procedures fail or not feasible go for IVF/GIFT 
Ovulation related           
  • Ovulation monitoring by ultrasound (BBT, BBI) And  Endometrial Biopsy for tuberculosis done    
  • If the above steps are abnormal, do a hormonal study
  • FSH, LH, Prolactin
  • E2, P level
  • Thyroid and diabetes
  • Clomiphene and letrozole
  • If it fails, give FSH, LH, GnRH
  • Check for a response; if there is no response do IVF Donor egg.
  • If all the above measures fail, the final option is to adopt  
Other causes   Ultrasound, MRI, SSG, hysteroscopy   Treat the cause

questions.text: A young female patient is undergoing evaluation for infertility. The cervical mucus shows the following appearance on microscopy. During which phase of the menstrual cycle is the given finding seen?

choices.text: Estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle

questions.solution:
The image shows a characteristic ferning pattern of cervical mucus seen during the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle. 

The characteristics of cervical mucous changes under the influence of estrogen and progesterone. During the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle, the cervical mucus is thin and stretchy due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus which shows the characteristic pattern seen above. This pattern disappears once ovulation has taken place due to the activity of progesterone. If previously present, its disappearance is presumptive evidence of corpus luteum activity.  

At the time of ovulation, the mucus becomes thin, watery, and clear that can be stretched up to 10cm. This is called spinnbarkeit or thread test and is presumptive of ovulation. During the progesterone phase, the mucus becomes thick and tenacious, impermeable to the sperms.

Other signs of ovulation are

  • An increase in basal body temperature(BBT) after ovulation due to the thermogenic action of the hormone progesterone. 
  • Urinary LH peak (increase in LH) is usually seen 1 day prior to ovulation.
  • The growth of ovarian follicles is 20 mm or more in size on USG at the time of ovulation.

The menstrual cycle consists of three phases: the menstrual phase, the proliferative phase, and the secretory, or progestational, phase

The menstrual phase is characterized by the discharge of blood and endometrial debris from the vagina due to the withdrawal of progesterone and the degeneration of the corpus luteum (CL).

The proliferative phase is estrogen-dominant and lasts from the end of menstruation to ovulation. It results in the proliferation of endometrial glands and thickened endometrium.

The secretory or progestational phase is progesterone dominant which converts the thickened, estrogen-primed endometrium to a richly vascularized, glycogen-filled tissue for early nourishment of a developing embryo. If fertilization and implantation do not occur, the corpus luteum degenerates and a new follicular phase and menstrual phase begin again.

Related Pearl: Hormonal Regulation of Menstrual Cycle

questions.text:
You are a medical officer on camp duty seeing patients who have come for the removal of contraceptive devices. You notice the following contraceptive devices being used. Which of the following is incorrect about these devices?

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease - PID

choices.text: Can be used as an emergency contraceptive
Can be used in patients with mennorrhagia
Functions by causing an inflammatory response within the uterus

questions.solution:
The image shows types of Copper T. The statement that it 'can be used in patients with menorrhagia' is incorrect about the copper T. Copper T's are contraindicated in patients with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, and anemia as it can worsen the condition. 

Copper T is a type of intrauterine contraception device (IUCD). They provide long-term, reversible method of contraception.

Types:

  • Medicated IUCD's such as progestasert, levonova, and mirena which release hormones for contraception.
  • Unmedicated IUCD's such as the copper T, in order to induce contraception. 

The copper T functions by causing an inflammatory response (Option D) within the uterus which leads to spermicide. The same response also makes it difficult for blastocyst implantation. 

IUCDs can be placed in women who have a low risk of sexually transmitted diseases, are multiparous, monogamous, and want long-term contraception without permanent sterilization. These have the advantage of not having to take a daily oral contraceptive pill. 

The copper T can also be used as emergency contraception (Option A) and left inside the uterus long term for contraception. 

It is contraindicated in the following situations: 

  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Fibroid uterus (Option C) as there will be structural issues
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease or lower genital tract infections
  • Menorrhagia or dysmenorrhea
  • Anemia
  • Uncontrolled diabetes due to increased risk of infection
  • Previous ectopic pregnancy 
  • Scarred uterus
  • Abnormally shaped uterus

In addition, hormonal IUCDs should not be given in women with history of breast cancer. 

The following image shows the Nova T. It has silver in addition to the copper wire which makes its lifespan 5 years. 

The copper T 380A is also known as Paraguard. It has a lifespan of 10 years. It has 380 mm2 surface area spread out across the stem and the sleeves. 

The multiload 375 has 375 mm2 of copper wire wrapped around the stem. It has to be replaced every 5 years. It does not have an introducer or plunger. 

The copper T 200 has 215mm2 of copper around the stem. It has a polyethylene frame with monofilaments attached to the end of the stem. The threads are used for removal. Barium sulfate is added to the stem to increase radioopacity when performing xrays. It has a lifespan of 3 years. 

The following images represent the copper T 380A, multiload 375, and copper T 200. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: Bleeding during normal menstruation occurs due to rupture of ____
questions.solution:
Rupture of the spiral arteries causes bleeding during normal menstruation. This is a branch of the uterine artery. 

The blood supply of the uterus is as follows:

Uterine artery→Arcuate artery→Radial artery→Basal artery→Spiral artery

questions.text: Menopause is defined as cessation of menses for a period of _____.
questions.solution: Menopause is defined as cessation of ovarian function for 12 months resulting in permanent amenorrhoea. It is a retrospective diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the OPD with fever, lower abdominal pain and purulent vaginal discharge. On examination, her vitals are stable and per vaginal examination reveals lower abdominal and cervical motion tenderness. What is the best treatment option for her?

choices.text: Single IM injection of ceftriaxone 250 mg with oral doxycycline and metronidazole for 14 days
Single IM injection of ceftriaxone 250 mg  with oral metronidazole 400 mg for 7 days
Oral doxycycline 100 mg BD with oral metronidazole  400 mg for 7 days
Oral ofloxacin 200 mg BD with oral metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever and lower abdominal pain associated with lower abdominal and cervical motion tenderness is suggestive of PID (Pelvic inflammatory disease). The best treatment option for this patient is outpatient treatment with a single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg + oral doxycycline 100 mg BD +/- metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days.

Outpatient treatment of PID (according to the current RCOG guidelines):

  • A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg + oral doxycycline 100 mg BD +/- metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days
  • A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by azithromycin 1 gm per week x 2 weeks.

Treatment of PID in hospitalized patients:

  • Cefotetan 2 g IV 12hourly + doxycycline 100 mg BD orally/ IV  for 48 hours is given followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg +/- metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days
  • Cefoxitin 2 g IV 6hourly + doxycycline 100 mg IV followed by oral route.
  • Azithromycin 500 mg IV 6 hourly for 2 days, then orally for Chlamydia.

questions.text: When does the ovary contain the maximum number of oogonia?
questions.solution:
The ovary contains the maximum number of oogonia at the 5th month of intrauterine life. The number of oogonia is estimated to be 7 million.

Oogenesis is the process wherein oogonia differentiate into mature oocytes. It begins before birth. At birth, there are approximately 2 million primordial follicles. At the initiation of puberty, the follicle count is less than 400,000, of which less than 500 are destined to ovulate. Every month, 15–20 follicles are released, out of which one matures to form the ovum.

questions.text: The non-contraceptive uses of oral contraceptives include all of the following except:

choices.text: Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer
Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV
Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer

questions.solution:
The non-contraceptive uses of oral contraceptives include all except protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.

Oral hormonal contraceptives can be combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) or progesterone-only minipills.

COCPs are a combination of ethinylestradiol at a dose of 20–30 mcg and an orally active progestogen. It is taken starting on the first day of the cycle for 21 days. They are taken at a fixed time of the day, preferably after a meal. Mala-N and Mala-D both contain levonorgestrel (0.15 mg) + ethinylestradiol (30 mcg). Mala-N is supplied free of cost in Family Planning Clinics in India. Each strip contains 21 hormonal tablets and 7 non-hormonal (iron) tablets. 

The mechanism of action is the prevention of ovulation by suppression of the pituitary hormones FSH and LH. Progesterone also acts on the cervical mucus, making it thick and impenetrable by sperm. The pregnancy rate with the COCP is 0.3 per 100 woman-years.

Benefits of the COCP:

  • It is effective in controlling fertility.
  • It causes regular cycles and reduces menstrual blood loss and are, therefore, useful in menorrhagia and polymenorrhea.
  • It lowers the incidence of benign breast neoplastic diseases, such as fibrocystic disease.
  • It reduces the incidence of functional ovarian cysts and ovarian (Option A) and endometrial malignancy (Option D). The incidence of ovarian cancer is reduced by 40% and that of uterine malignancy, by 50%, if taken for 1 year; this effect lasts as long as 10 years after stoppage.
  • It reduces the incidence of ectopic pregnancy (Option B) by suppressing ovulation and reducing the risk in pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • It is useful in endometriosis, acne, and polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD).

Side effects:

  • Higher incidence of breast cancer reported among users
  • Suppression of lactation
  • Occurrence of pituitary adenoma and adenoma of the liver
  • Reduced carbohydrate tolerance (therefore, contraindicated in diabetic women)
  • Migraine, depression, weight gain, and lethargy (due to progesterone)
  • Increased risk of pulmonary embolism and cerebral thrombosis

Ninety-nine percent of women will regain normal menstrual cycles within 6 months of stopping the pills, while the return of fertility is slightly delayed.

Barrier methods like condoms prevent the transmission of STDs.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: Given below are the four causes of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) with the corresponding class of a PALM-COEIN classification. Which is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The polycystic ovarian disease is an ovarian cause of abnormal uterine bleeding which comes under AUB-O, in the PALM-COEIN classification.

AUB in the reproductive age group was previously known as dysfunctional uterine bleeding, however, that term is now obsolete. AUB can be acute or chronic:

  • Acute AUB - it can start sporadically or be superimposed on chronic AUB.
  • Chronic AUB - it lasts for 6 months (3 months minimum).

PALM-COEIN classification of AUB:

  • Polyp (AUB-P):
    • Endometrial polyps
    • Endocervical polyps
  • Adenomyosis (AUB-A)
  • Leiomyoma (AUB-L). Fibroids are further classified as:
    • Submucosal (SM)
    • Other (O)
  • Malignancy and hyperplasia (AUB-M) 
    • Endometrial hyperplasia 
    • Endometrial carcinoma
  • Coagulopathy (AUB-C)
    • von Willebrand's disease
    • Hemophilias
  • Ovarian causes (AUB-O)
    • PCOD
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Hyperprolactinemia.  
  • Endometrial causes (AUB-E)
    • Tubercular or chlamydial endometritis 
  • Iatrogenic causes (AUB-I)
    • Intrauterine contraceptive devices
    • Anticoagulants
    • Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Not yet classified (AUB-N) includes rare causes such as
    • Arteriovenous malformations 
    • Myometrial hypertrophy

questions.text: You have posted a 43-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding for dilatation and curettage in the minor OT.  Identify the following instrument used in this procedure.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Sim's curette. It is a single-ended uterine curette used for dilatation and curettage.

It is designed to remove tough tissue from the lining of the uterus for biopsy or excision. The curette features a sharp loop tip to aid in the removal of the uterine tissue.
